position.marginalia_text: Militia est, vita hominis super terram. Concurrunt Equites Cataphractè vtrinq[ue] Düello:
Ἒν δὲ πύλῃ πóλεμου ἔνγραφος ἐστὶ νόμος.
Gloria proposita est Victori: Infamia Victo:
Ẻκ σκοπιᾶς δὲ ὁρᾷ ἀρχὸς ἀγωνοθέτης.
Militia est, ha[e]c Vita hominis, dum viuit in orbe:
Scripta palàm, Lex est, in Mose, Euangelioq[ue]:
Πάντες ἴασι: μόνος αλλὰ βραβεῖον ἔχει.
Quid magis est durum saxo? quid mollius vnda? Dura tamen molli saxa cauantur aqua.
Πέτραν κο[ι]λαίνει ῤανὶς ὕδατος ἐνδελεχείη Καὶ πόνος ἐνδελεχὴς πράγματα πάντα τελεῖ.

È Pamphili Eudromi Entelechia. Vbi etiam simile Thema: In sudore Vultus tui, vesceris Pane tuo. In victoriam dolo partam; Alciati Emblema. Aiacis Tumulum, lachrymis ego perluo Virtus, Heu misera ablentes dilacerata comas. Scillicèt hoc restabat adhuc, Vt Iudire Gra[e]co Vincere[r]; et causa stet potiore Dolus. Consilio, et Virtute, Chimeyram superari; Eiusdem Emblema. Bellerophon vt fortis Eques superare Chimaeram, Et Licii potuit sternere monstra soli: Sic tu Pegaseis vectus petis a[e]thera pennis, Consilioq[ue] animi, monstra superba domas. A minimis quoq[ue] timendum: praesertim astutis. Eiusde[m]. Bella gerit Scaraba[e]us, et hostem prouocat vltrò; Robores et Inferior, Consilio Superat. Nam plumis Aquila[e] clam se, neq[ue] cognitus abdit, Hostilem vt nidum summa per astra petat: Ouaq[ue] confodiens, prohibet spem crescere prolis: Hocq[ue] modo illatum dedecus Vltus, abit. Non vulganda Consilia. Eiusdem. Limine quod ca[e]co, obscura et Caligine, monstrum Gnosiacis clausit Da[e]dalus in Latebris: Depictum Romana Phalanx in pra[e]lia gestat; Semiuiroq[ue] nitent signa superba Boue. Nosq[ue] monent, Debere Ducum Secreta [manere deleted] latere Consilia: Auctori cognita Techna nocet.

marginalia.translation:
Man's life upon earth is war. Armored horsemen clash in war: It is inscribed on the gates of war: Glory is given to the victor; shame to the conquered. From a high tower the lord and master of contests watches. This human life, while we live on earth, is war: The one watching from heaven is God the King. It is clearly written, the Law is, in Moses and the Gospel: All run, but only one takes the prize. What is harder than rock, or softer than water? Yet hard stones are hollowed by soft water. With persistence the drop of water hollows out the stone: And persistent labor brings all deeds to their end.
From the Activity of Eudromus Pamphili. Where also on the same theme: by the sweat of your brow, you shall eat your bread.
On a victory acquired through deceit; an emblem by Alciati. I, Virtue, soak the tomb of Ajax with my tears, alas, wretched, having rent my whitening hair. Certainly this matter still remained, that by a Greek judge I should be vanquished; and that deceit be a stronger defense.
Through deliberation and virtue the Chimaera is overcome; an emblem by the same. As the courageous horseman Bellerophon was able to overcome the Chimaera, And slay the monsters of the Lycian land, So you, carried on Pegasean wings, seek the heavens, And by the judgment of your mind, subdue tyrannical monsters.
Even the weakest must be feared: especially the cunning. By the same. The beetle wages war, and provokes the enemy willingly; even though inferior in strength; he surpasses in deliberation. For he hides himself in secret and unknown in the feathers of the eagle, to reach his enemy's nest through the highest stars: And by piercing the eggs, he puts an end to the hope of the young growing up: And in this way having avenged the shame inflicted, he departs.
Plans not to be divulged. Of the same. With a hidden threshold, and thick darkness, Daedalus shut up the monster in the lairs of Knossos: The Roman phalanx carries this depiction into battle; and these standards, with a half-man bull, shine forth splendidly. And they warn us that the secret plans of leaders ought to lie hidden: a strategy which is known harms its author.
